pr_title: Define metrics for ISet and IList collections (#3823)

timeline.bodyText: Do we need to initialize this with 1000 capacity? It feels a waste of heap in the typical case.
timeline.author: blazember

timeline.bodyText: It is safe to ignore this class and the related tests in this PR. This class was used for passing the metrics/statistics to Management Center, but starting with 4.1 we are going to use the metrics system introduced in 4.0 - what uses the DynamicMetricsProvider interface that you already implemented - for that purpose.
timeline.author: blazember

replies.bodyText: OK, I see. Shall I revert these changes then or are they fine as they are?
replies.author: aberkecz

replies.bodyText: No strong preference here, but I'd remove it to keep the PR smaller.
replies.author: blazember

timeline.bodyText: I think there should be separate types for list and set statistics. If we make them returning the same type of stats, we can't evolve the API differently for the two data structures. For example, if we want to introduce numberOfIndexOutOfBounds later, we can't do it without introducing it for sets too, where it doesn't make too much sense.
timeline.author: blazember
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -34,4 +34,14 @@
  * @see List
  */
 public interface IList<E> extends List<E>, ICollection<E> {
+
+
+    /**
+     * Returns {@link LocalCollectionStats} for this collection.
+     * LocalCollectionStats is the statistics for this collection.
+     *
+     * @return this collection's local statistics.
+     */
+    LocalCollectionStats getLocalCollectionStats();

timeline.bodyText: I'm actually not sure this is a really useful stat for lists and sets. For maps and caches it makes sense, since those typically perform lookup operations. But lists and sets have different use cases. In that sense, I think these two are closer to queues and topics that don't have hits in their stats. The closest operations I can think of are contains and indexOf (in the case of list), but I'm not quite sure this is needed.
timeline.author: blazember
timeline.diffHunk:

+package com.hazelcast.collection;
+
+import com.hazelcast.instance.LocalInstanceStats;
+import com.hazelcast.internal.monitor.MemberState;
+
+/**
+ * Local collections statistics to be used by {@link MemberState} implementations.
+ */
+public interface LocalCollectionStats extends LocalInstanceStats {
+
+    /**
+     * Returns the last access (read) time of the list.
+     *
+     * @return last access (read) time of the list.
+     */
+    long getLastAccessTime();
+
+    /**
+     * Returns the last update time of the list.
+     *
+     * @return last update time of the list.
+     */
+    long getLastUpdateTime();
+
+    /**
+     * Returns the number of hits (reads) of the list, including those read operations
+     * that do not return with a value (eg.: {@link IList#indexOf(Object)}.
+     *
+     * @return the number of hits (reads) of the list.
+     */
+    long getNumberOfHits();

timeline.bodyText: If we introduce separate types for the stats, this might not be needed.

replies.bodyText: Oops, I must've missed it during the refactor. Thanks for pointing that out!
replies.author: aberkecz

timeline.bodyText: This and the constructor function can be moved to the actual list and set implementations and then no need for the casts in them. I think only getLocalCollectionStats() is needed here.
timeline.author: blazember

timeline.bodyText: Do we need the assertTrueEventually() in these methods? In the concrete tests a reference is obtained to the stats instance, which means, by the time the operations return the stats instance is updated.
timeline.author: blazember

replies.bodyText:
I tried removing the assertTrueEventually block but the tests failed then. I don't fully understand why is it like that but I originally I did it this way because I went by the QueueStatisticsTest class.
Shall I do a deeper investigation on this?
replies.author: aberkecz
blazember

replies.bodyText:
I'm not sure I fully understand your proposition. In the ListStatisticsTest class I check and save the lastUpdateTime after each operation. For example, before I test the list.contains(o) method, I save the previous updateTime (after testing the `list.get(0) method).
I suppose this check is not sufficient enough but I don't understand why. :(
(I am happy to make the changes you requested but wanted to ask for some clarification so I fully understand what's happening.)
replies.author: aberkecz
blazember

replies.bodyText: Thanks @blazember for the detailed explanation! Now it's perfectly clear for me. The missing part for me was the fact that the afterRun method runs asynchronously. Let me fix the tests and get back to you ASAP.
replies.author: aberkecz

replies.bodyText: You're absolutely right. The second line doesn't really provide any additional information so I deleted them both in the IList and ISet interfaces.
replies.author: aberkecz

timeline.message: Define metrics for ISet and IList collections (#3823)
Remove `initialCapacity` argument from `statsMap`'s constructor to save heap size

Perform fixes after code review

Add stats to `DistributedDatastructuresMetricsTest`
Introduce separate statistics for `IList` and `ISet`
Remove `numberOfHits` metric from `IList` and `ISet`
Revert modifications in `MemberStateImpl` and `TimedMemberStateFactory`
Introduce separate `MetricDescriptorConstants` for `IList` and `ISet`
Add the `ParallelJVMTest` category to newly introduced test classes

Implement changes recommended during the the code review process

Details: https://github.com/hazelcast/hazelcast/pull/16665#pullrequestreview-367892255
Clarify JavaDoc for `getLocalListStats` and `getLocalSetStats` methods in `IList` and `ISet`
Fix asserting for non-modified `lastUpdateTime` metric values in `ListStatisticsTest` and `SetStatisticsSet` test classes
Introduce wait time between doubled operations to assure that the `lastAccessTime` metrics differ in these cases
Introduce wait time between doubled operations to assure that the `lastAccessTime` metrics differ in these cases
